title: Am I financially responsible for my husband's business?
question: Do I already have rights to the business by being married to him? Do I assume all debt? What if we got a divorce, what rights do I have with not having the shares?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce settlement agreements,Alimony,Divorce and bankruptcy,Prenups and divorce,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Prenuptial agreement,Marital property
answers:
Under California community property laws, you are entitled to 50% ownership of everything your husband earned during the marriage- unless otherwise agreed to in writing. If he already had ownership interest of the corporation (which it sounds like he did) when you got married, then the corporate shares would be considered his separate property. A corporation is designed to protect its owners from personal liability, so assuming the corporate formalities have been followed, and he transfers 40% ownership interest to you, you should not be personally liable for debts of the corporation, but liable only to the extent of your ownership interest. In other words, you may have to give up your interest if the company gets too heavily in debt, but your personal property should be safe.

The foregoing is not legal advise and should not be relied upon as such. As with the others on this list, I recommend you visit a business lawyer or family law lawyer to get advice you can rely on.

Considering thaty your husband is in an active business, and has been, and wants to give you a 40% share (whatever that might mean), you and your husband may find it to be a very smart step to actually go meet with a local business lawyer (a 1 hour meeting, as a paid consultation, most likely not costing over $350), and let the attorney know you are looking for a new business attorney. You can discuss the current structure, your plan, and come away with lots of solid advice for making not only this decision, but a good plan for moving forward. Otherwise, even using this forum, you are merely guessing and hoping .... and that can result in disaster.

You should not assume that the business is community property. How long have you been married? How long has he owned the business? Whose funds were used to start the business? Did you work for the business? Was there a pre-nuptial agreement? For example if he has owned the business for twenty years and you have been married for only two years, then it is likely not community property. That means he owns it as his separate property, so you would have no ownership in the business. If the facts were reversed—20 years of marriage and two years of ownership and community funds were used to buy or start the business, then is pretty clear that the business, and its shares owned by him, are community property (CP), so you would own half of the business. If it is CP, then you are responsible for one half of the related debts. Regardless you would probably be entitled to a share of the business income by way of spousal support, that is, alimony.
The gift of shares from CP may increase your ownership, rather that limit it. If it is truly a gift of 40%, then a court might find that he had given away shares from his own share of CP, so he would have only 10% left and you would own 90% of the business. More likely a court would refuse to honor the transfer of shares except as follows: Generally a couple is not able to change the nature of ownership of marital property during the marriage unless a written Agreement is made and each party is represented by a different, independent lawyer at the time. So you need to consult your own counsel to determine whether the business is CP or SP, and to have her draft an Agreement between you and your husband stating exactly what property is to be transferred and whether the shares will be CP or SP after the gift. Your husband should then go to an independent lawyer for counsel on whether to sign it or try to negotiate changes.

You have "community property" rights to 1/2 of everything your husband earns during your marriage, including his business income, and you also get 1/2 of the debt incurred during your marriage.

If your husband formed this business during the marriage, you'd be entitled to 1/2, so is he offering you a 40% ownership interest in the business because he knows you're entitled to 50%, or is this part of a divorce settlement? If you're getting divorced and there are significant assets to divide, you should get full disclosures from him what he's got and have your own family lawyer review your respective situations and give you some specific advice.
